Replace.Text: Each citizen in the city provides 0.5 [ICON_Production] productivity, and the city's [ICON_FOOD] food growth is +20%.
Each citizen in the city provides 0.3 [ICON_Culture] culture, and farms provide +1 [ICON_Food] food.

The cost of building a theater square is halved, the Ancient Roman Theater gains +2 [ICON_Faith] Faith points, and +1 [ICON_GreatWriter] Great Writer point. [ICON_GreatWork_Writing] Literary Works gain +2 [ICON_Science] Science points, +2 [ICON_Faith] Faith points, and the [ICON_Tourism] tourism performance is doubled. The Library gains +2 [ICON_Culture] Culture points, and has an additional [ICON_GreatWork_Writing] Great Work slot.

Donghuang unique building, replaces the monument. +1 [ICON_Food] Food, +1 [ICON_SCIENCE] Science, +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, +1 [ICON_Production] Productivity, +1 [ICON_FAITH] Faith, +1 [ICON_Amenities] Amenities. Does not provide loyalty.

Donghuang Specialty Area, replaces the Community, appears earlier, and has a higher maintenance cost. +4 [ICON_Housing] Housing, +2 [ICON_Housing] when built on a plot with Stunning Charm, +1 [ICON_Housing] when it reaches Charming +4 [ICON_Amenities] Amenities, unlike the Community, too low Charm will not reduce Housing and provides two citizen slots. Gives the standard bonus to adjacent Specialty Areas, and obtains certain bonuses from nearby Specialty Areas. +3 [ICON_Food] Food when adjacent to another Guhuang Market, +1 [ICON_Culture] Culture when adjacent to two other Guhuang Markets, +1 [ICON_Production] Productivity if there is a river nearby. [NEWLINE] Each completed Guhuang Market will speed up the progress of the current municipality by 5% (if it exists)
Donghuang's unique anti-cavalry unit, replacing the Spearman. Has higher [ICON_Strength] combat power, and +20 [ICON_Strength] combat power when defending against attacks from ranged units.

The origin of firecrackers has a history of more than 2,000 years. In ancient China, when there was no gunpowder or paper, people used fire to burn bamboo to make it burst and make noises to drive away the plague god. Because the burning bamboo made a "crackling" sound, it was called firecrackers. Setting off firecrackers on festivals or festive days reflects the good wishes of the ancient Chinese working people for peace and security.
